WRITE_TEXT.description:
Write text to the LCD.
Writes a NULL (00000000B) terminated string to the LCD.
Location of the string is provided using the DPTR register.

WRITE_DATA.description:
Write character to the LCD.
Writes a byte stored in the Accumulator to the LCD as an ASCII character.

WRITE_HEX.detail: Write hexadecimal number to the LCD
WRITE_HEX.description:
Write hexadecimal number to the LCD.
Writes a byte stored in the Accumulator to the LCD as a hexadecimal number.

WRITE_INSTR.detail: Send an instruction to the LCD
WRITE_INSTR.description:
Send an instruction to the LCD.
Sends a byte stored in the Accumulator to the LCD as an instruction.

LCD_CLR.description: Clear the LCD and move the cursor to the beginning.

DELAY_US.description:
Pauses the program execution for the time, in microseconds, calculated by the formula
`(A * 2 + 6) * 12 / 11.0592` [μs] 
where A is a value stored in the Accumulator.
Resulting wait time ranges between around 6.5 μs and 559.9 μs.

DELAY_MS.description:
Pauses the program execution for the time, in milliseconds, stored in the Accumulator.
Execution will be paused for 256 ms if the value stored in the Accumulator is equal to 0.
Resulting wait time ranges between 1 ms and 256 ms.

DELAY_100MS.description:
Pauses the program execution for the time, in milliseconds, stored in the Accumulator multiplied by a 100.
Execution will be paused for 25.6 s if the value stored in the Accumulator is equal to 0.
Resulting wait time ranges between 100 ms and 25.6 s.

WAIT_ENTER.description: Write "PRESS ENTER..." to the LCD and wait for the user to press the Enter key

WAIT_ENTER_NW.description: Wait for the user to press the Enter key, without writing anything to the LCD

TEST_ENTER.description: Check if the Enter key is pressed.

WAIT_ENT_ESC.description: Wait for user to press either the Enter key or the Escape key.

WAIT_KEY.description:
Wait for a user to press any key on the matrix keypad.
Number of key pressed is stored in the Accumulator

GET_NUM.description:
Ask user for up to 4 BCD digits and store them in the memory location pointed by @R0 register.
To finish inputing a number user can either
 - Press the Enter key
 - Press the Esc key
 - Type 4 digits

affected_flags.when_unset: User typed 4 digits or pressed Esc

BCD_HEX.description:
Converts two byte BCD number, stored in the memory location pointed by @R0 register, to a hexadecimal representation of that number,
and stores the result in the same two bytes pointed by the @R0 register.

HEX_BCD.description:
Converts two byte hexadecimal number, stored in the memory location pointed by @R0 register, to a three byte BCD representation of that number,
and stores the result in the memory location pointed by @R0 register.

MUL_2_2.description:
Multiplies a two-byte number stored in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register 
with a two-byte number stored in the B register (higher byte) and the Accumulator (lower byte).

The result will be stored as a four-byte number in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register

MUL_3_1.detail: Multiply three-byte number by a one-byte number
MUL_3_1.description:
Multiplies a three-byte number stored in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register 
with a number stored in the Accumulator.

The result will be stored as a four-byte number in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register

DIV_2_1.detail: Divide two-byte number by a one-byte number
DIV_2_1.description:
Divides a two-byte number stored in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register 
by a number stored in the B register.

The result will be stored as a two-byte number in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register, 
and the reminder will be stored in the Accumulator

DIV_4_2.detail: Divide four-byte number by a two-byte number
DIV_4_2.description:
Divides a four-byte number stored in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register 
by a number stored in the B register (higher byte) and the Accumulator (lower byte).

The result will be stored as a four-byte number in the memory location pointed by the @R0 register,
and the reminder will be stored as a two-byte number in the location four bytes after the memory address in the R0 register ( @(R0+4) ).
